document.masterDocTitle: A revision of Palaearctic Anthobium Leach, 1819 (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae Omaliinae: Anthophagini). V. Algidum, morosum and tectum groups, a new species of the fusculum group, and faunistic records

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of Palaearctic Anthobium Leach, 1819 (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae Omaliinae: Anthophagini). V. Algidum, morosum and tectum groups, a new species of the fusculum group, and faunistic records

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 26–28. Habitus (Fig. 26; paratype) and aedeagus (Figs. 27—28) of
Anthobium morosum
: 27—parameral view, 28—lateral view. Scale bar: 1.0 mm (Fig. 26), 0.1 mm (Figs. 27–28).

FIGURES 29–33. Mouthparts (dorsal view) of
Anthobium morosum
: 29—labrum, 30—mandibles (left and right), 31—maxilla (left), 32—labium, 33—mentum. Scale bar: 0.1 mm.

FIGURES 34–45.
Anthobium morosum
: 34—ventral aspect of head (ventral view), 35—ventral aspect of prothorax (ventral view), 36—scutellum (dorsal view), 37—ventral aspect of elytron, 38—ventral aspect of mesoventrite, 39—ventral aspect of metaventrite (without metanepisternum), 40—metendosternite (ventral view), 41—male abdominal tergite VIII (dorsal view), 42—male abdominal sternite VIII (ventral view), 43—female abdominal tergite VIII (dorsal view), 44—female abdominal sternite VIII (ventral view), 45—female genital segment (ventral view). Scale bar: 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Legs long and slender, with very dense and long setation on pro- and mesotibiae, with additional long and moderately dense setae on inner sides, setation of metatibiae somewhat finer and sparser, with several stout setae around apical margin of each mesotibiae; middle and apical portions of inner sides of pro- and mesotibiae with two long rows of short peg-setae; pro- and mesotarsi twice longer than tibiae, metatarsi two and a half times as long as metatibia; apical metatarsomere of all tarsi about as long as three preceding combined tarsomeres.
Distribution. The new species is at present known only from the type locality in central Nepal ( Fig. 93 ).
Natural history. The specimens were collected at an elevation 2800 m a.s.l. Detailed ecological data are unknown.
Etymology. The specific epithet (Latin adjective: strange) alludes to the unusual shapes of some morphological structures of the body.
